allow.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to let someone do or have something, or let something happen
allow.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Are dictionaries allowed in the exam?
something is allowed
Students should be allowed to make their own decisions.
somebody should be allowed to do something
My parents wouldn’t allow me to go to the party.
allow somebody to do something
Students are not allowed to eat in class.
allow somebody to do something
Passengers are allowed one item of hand luggage each.
allow somebody something
How much time are we allowed?
allow somebody something
He allowed himself the occasional glass of wine.
allow yourself something
We don’t allow diving in the pool.
allow something
I don’t allow the cat in the bedroom.
allow somebody in/out/up etc
The audience is not allowed backstage.
allow somebody in/out/up etc
Don’t allow your problems to dominate your life.
allow something to do something
allow.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to make it possible for something to happen or for someone to do something, especially something helpful or useful
allow.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Our new system will allow for more efficient use of resources.
A 24-hour ceasefire allowed the two armies to reach an agreement.
a seat belt that allows the driver greater freedom of movement
This adjustment of the figures allows a fairer comparison.
allow.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to be sure that you have enough time, money, food etc available for a particular purpose
allow.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Allow yourselves plenty of time to get to the airport.
I’ve allowed half a bottle of wine for each person.
allow.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to accept that something is correct or true, or that something is acceptable according to the rules or law
allow.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: I allow that there may have been a mistake.
allow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: You allow someone to do something
Her boss allows her to work from home
allow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: Allow is often used in the passive
allow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3: Her boss lets her work from home
allow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4: Let is not used in the passive
allow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[6: Someone is permitted to do something
Employees are permitted to work from home
allow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[7: Permit is usually used in the passive
allow.translation[0].note_box[1].section: to say that someone can do something – used about parents, teachers, or people in authority
They don’t allow students to chew gum in the classroom.
I’m not allowed to stay out after ten o'clock.
to allow someone to do something. Let is not used in the passive, and is much more commonly used in everyday English than allow
Will your mum let you come to the party?
I’ll borrow John’s bicycle, if he’ll let me.
if something is permitted, it is allowed according to the rules – used especially on written notices and announcements
Smoking is not permitted anywhere in the building.
give somebody permission
used when someone in an important official position decides to allow someone to do something
He was given special permission to leave school early.
The Home Office has given him permission to stay in Britain indefinitely.
give your consent
to say that you will allow someone to do something that will affect you personally, or a member of your family, when you have a legal right to say ‘no’
Her parents have given their consent to the marriage.
You can’t build on someone’s land without the owner’s consent.
give something the go-ahead
to officially allow a planned project or activity to happen
The government finally gave the go-ahead for a new terminal at Heathrow airport.
A new nuclear plant has been given the go-ahead.
authorize
to officially or legally allow someone to do something – used about laws or people
The UN resolution would authorize the use of force.
I never authorized them to give information about me to other banks.
entitle
to give someone the right to do or have something
The pass entitles you to travel on any bus, at any time, in Norwich.
If the goods are faulty, the customer is entitled to a refund.
sanction
to give official approval and support for something
The Truman administration refused to sanction a military attack.
The advertisements were sanctioned by the candidate himself.
allow.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: when the tax authorities allow an amount, cost, or expense, they permit it not to be counted as part of income or profits
allow.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: You’re allowed a certain amount a year in personal allowances, before you have to pay any tax.
allow.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to decide that an amount of money claimed for insurance, damages etc is correct and should be paid
allow.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The judge allowed claims against the company involving unpaid dividends and disallowed others.
